$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the N-arylation
Reaction. A mixture of NHC copper catalyst 4 (0.5 mmol %), arylboronic
acid (1.0 mmol), and azole or amine (0.5 mmol) in 3 mL of CH3OH was
stirred under an atmosphere of air at room temperature for 36 h. Then the
mixture was centrifuged and the centrifugate was evaporated to dryness
under reduced pressure. The residue was resolved in 20 mL of ethyl
acetate and washed with saturated brine (20 mL 3). After the organic
layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, itwas concentrated to ca. 1mL. The
residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide
the desired product. 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM air/oxidant used

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1311157-16-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):AMD
$DATUM polymer-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: In a 100 mL RB flask, Cu-PAR (0.05 g, 0.0129
mmol), arylboronic acid (1 mmol), N-H heterocycles (1.2 mmol), and 10 mL
methanol were stirred under nitrogen atmosphere, at 40 °C. The reaction
mixtures were collected at different time interval and identified by GCMS
and quantified by GC analysis. After the completion of the reaction, the
catalyst was filtered off and washed with water fol- lowed by acetone and
dried in oven. The filtrate was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL)
and the com- bined organic layers were dried with anhydrous Na2SO4 by
vacuum. The filtrate was concentrated by vacuum and the resulting residue
was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the
desired product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (A). Time (h): 12, Isolated Yield
(%): 97. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.53-7.44 (m, 2H),
7.42-7.35 (m, 3H), 7.28 (bs, 1H), 7.21 (bs, 1H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3)
δ 136.1, 134.5, 130.1, 129.3, 127.4, 121.3, 118.2.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, catalyst prepared and used, chloromethylated
polystyrene-supported copper(II) 4-(2-pyridylazo)resorcinol complex
catalyst used, reused catalyst gave moderately lower yield, alternative
preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An Efficient Recyclable Polymer Supported Copper(II) Catalyst for C-N
Bond Formation by N-Arylation
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Tuhina, Kazi; Mobarok, Manir; Paul, Sumantra; Salam, Noor; Hossain,
Dildar
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Catalysis Letters (2011), 141(8), 1171-1181

$DATUM 121-44-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-Benzoylimidazole: General procedure for the preparation of
acyl-imidazoles and -pyrazoles: In a typical experiment imidazole (20
mmol) was dissolved in distilled CH2Cl2 (20 mL) containing TEA (20 mmol)
and cooled to 0 degC under a steady flow of argon. The requisite acid
chloride (20 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 (distilled) was delivered
dropwise over several minutes to the stirring solution imidazole solution
at 0 degC. The mixture was allowed to warm to 25 degC and stirred at this
temperature for 2 hr to ensure completion. The reaction mixture was then
diluted with 100 mL of diethyl ether, filtered and evaporated under
reduced pressure. Purification through silica gel with hexanes:ethyl
acetate (3:1) furnished 100 % yields. According to the general procedure,
the product was obtained. 3.4 g (98 %); pale yellow liquid.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Indium-mediated allylations in aqueous media: an expansion of the scope
and a demonstration of the synthetic utility of the reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bryan, Vernal Jermaine
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM (2000), 62(12), 157 pages

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Acylation Acyl
chloride (acetyl or benzoyl chloride) (1.05 mmol) was added to a stirred
mixture of the amine 1 or 2 (1 mmol) and iodine (1 mmol), and stirring
continued between two additions at room temperature for the appropriate
time as monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC). In case of solid
substrate, 3.5 eqv of the acyl chloride were used to solubilize the
substrate. After completion of the reaction, iodine was destroyed by
adding saturated Na2S2O3 solution (5 ml). Diethyl ether (10 ml) was
added, and the two phases were separated. The organic phase was washed
with saturated NaHCO3 solution (2.5 ml) and brine (2.5 ml), dried
(Na2SO4), and concentrated to give the pure product. Entry ed (4e), yield
97.32% (melting point 100 °C) 1H NMR: 7.25 (s, 1H), 7.5 (m, 1H), 7.65 (m,
1H), 8.1 (m, 5H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM no solvent in stage 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild and Useful Method for N-Acylation of Amines
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Phukan, Kandarpa; Ganguly, Mausumi; Devi, Nirada
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2009), 39(15), 2694-2701

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 960242-97-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):AMD
$DATUM reaction products with sodium hydroxide and L-proline
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 960243-04-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):AMD
$DATUM polystyrene-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl
Halides. A flamedried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was
charged with CuI (9.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), 4a-2 (145 mg, 0.1 mmol of the
L-proline unit), K2CO3 (165 mg, 1.2 mmol), nitrogen-containing
heterocycle (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide (0.6 mmol), and DMSO (2
mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the
system was then evacuated three times and backfilled with N2. The
reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then
heated at 120 °C for 60 h. The resulting mixture was cooled to ambient
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a
plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl acetate. The
filtrate was concentrated, and the resulting residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired product.
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (6m)1 Following the general procedure,
imidazole (0.034 g, 0.5 mmol) was coupled with 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene
(0.095 g, 0.6 mmol) for 60 h at 90 ºC. The crude product was purified
over a silica gel column using ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give a
pale yellow solid (97% yield). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.30 (s, 1H),
7.39 (s, 1H), 7.59 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 8.04 (s, 1H), 8.39 (d, J = 9.0
Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 117.6, 121.0, 125.7, 131.7,
135.4, 141.9, 146.2 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 189 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst (polymer-supported ionic liq. and its copper
complex)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Concept of Supported Amino Acid Ionic Liquids and Their Application in
Metal Scavenging and Heterogeneous Catalysis
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chen, Wen; Zhang, Yuanyuan; Zhu, Liangbo; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129(45), 13879-13886

$DATUM 25322-68-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for the Coupling Reaction A Schlenk tube with a
magnetic stirring bar was charged with imidazole (2.4 mmol), K2CO3 (4.2
mmol), CuI (0.16 mmol, 10 mol%), aryl halide (2.0 mmol), and PEG (3 mL).
The tube was sealed after being evacuated twice and back filled with N2.
The mixture was stirred at 110°C for 24 h, cooled to room temperature,
and extracted with diethyl ether (5×10mL). The upper layers were
decanted, combined, and concentrated to the crude product, which was
analyzed by GC-MS. The PEG phase of the lower layer was subjected to a
second run with the same substrates. Further purification of the product
was achieved by flash chromatography on a silica-gel column. All the
products, which are known compounds, were characterized and compared with
authentic compounds previously reported in the literatures.[9a,9b,12,15]
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 2, Entry 11). 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 8.38 (d, 2H, J = 9.0 Hz), 8.01 (s, 1H), 7.60 (d, 2H, J = 9.0
Hz), 7.41 (s, 1H), 7.31 (s, 1H). GC-MS (EI, m/z): 188.9 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, alternative preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Efficient and Reusable Catalytic System of CuI-PEG for N-Arylation of
Imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Qiang; Luo, Jun; Wei, Yunyang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(1), 114-121

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure. An oven-dried 25 mL
round-bottomed flask with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with CuI
nanoparticles (1.25 mol %), K2CO3 (0.1662 g, 1.2 mmol),
nitrogencontaining heterocycle (1.2 mmol)/phenol (1.2 mmol), aryl
chloride (1.0 mmol), and DMF (1 mL) under air. The reaction mixture was
stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then transferred to a
preheated oil bath at 110 °C. At the end of the reaction, as judged by
TLC, the reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature, diluted
with 2-3 mL of EtOAc, and centrifuged to remove the catalyst, and the
catalyst was further washed with 5-10 mL of EtOAc to make it free from
organic matter. The combined organic extracts were then concentrated
under reduced pressure, and the resulting residue was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (60-120) using hexane/ethyl acetate (80:20)
eluent to provide the desired N-arylated/ O-arylated product. The
catalyst was oven-dried at 65 °C for 2 h and reused.
1-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table 2, Entry 4): Pale yellow solid, 95
%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, ppm): δ 7.25 (s, 1H), 7.39 (s, 1H), 7.57 (d, J
= 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.95 (s, 1H), 8.38 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3, ppm): δ 117.6, 120.9, 125.7, 131.7, 135.4, 141.9, 146.3. EI-MS:
m/z = 189 (M+).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM CuI nanoparticles used as cat..

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Solvent-Free, Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
a Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycle; General Procedure A mixture of
nitrogen-containing heterocycle 1 (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide 2
(0.6 mmol), cubic Cu2O nanoparticles (5-10 mol%), 1,10-phenanthroline
(L2; 10-20 mol%), and TBAF (1.5 mmol) was stirred at 110-145 °C for 24-48
h until complete consumption of the starting material was observed
(monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, EtOAc (10 mL) was
poured into the mixture, which was then washed with sat. aq NaCl (3 × 5
mL) and extracted with Et2O (2 × 10 mL). The organic layers were then
dried (anhyd Na2SO4) and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc or hexane-EtOAc) to afford
the desired product. 1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (3)5d, yield 95%. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.40 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 8.01 (s, 1 H), 7.61
(d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 7.41 (s, 1 H), 7.29 (s, 1 H). 13C NMR (125 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 146.5, 142.0, 135.4, 131.8, 125.7, 121.1, 117.6. LRMS (EI, 70
eV): m/z (%) = 189 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM optimized on copper catalyst and ligand, nanoparticle Cu⊂2O as catalyst,
optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-arylations of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides using a copper(I) oxide nanoparticle/1,10-phenanthroline
catalytic system
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2008), (11), 1707-1716

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (3r)2 Following the general procedure, a
pale yellow solid was obtained (95% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ
7.27 (s, 1H), 7.34 (s, 1H), 7.53 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.80 (d, J = 8.4
Hz, 2H), 8.00 (s, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 117.6, 121.0,
125.7, 131.7, 135.4, 141.9, 146.2 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 189 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple Copper Salt-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Guo, Peng; Li, Gaocan; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(22), 8535-8538

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2.4. General Procedure for the Aza-Michael
Reaction of Imidazole with α,β-Unsaturated Compounds Using Cu(acac)2in
Ionic Liquids. To the solution of Cu(acac)2 (0.005 g, 2 mol %) in ionic
liquid (1 mL), imidazole (1 mmol) and α,β-unsaturated compound (1.2 mmol)
were added and stirred at 60°C for the appropriate time (see Table 2,
presented later in this paper). After completion of the reaction, as
indicated by TLC, the product was extracted with a 1:1 ethyl
acetate:n-hexane mixture (3 x 10 mL). The combined organic extracts were
concentrated under reduced pressure and purified by column chromatography
on silica gel to afford the pure product. The recovered ionic liquid
phase that contained Cu(acac)2 was dried under reduced pressure for the
next runs. The products were characterized by comparison of their nuclear
magnetic resonance (NMR) and mass spectra with those reported in the
literature. 24,26,39 entry 7, yield 95%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM absence of catalyst gave lower (moderate) yield, alternative reaction
conditions shown, alternative solvents and temperatures gave lower yield,
aza-Michael reaction, ionic liquid used, optimization study, optimized on
solvent,temperature,time

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling Reaction A
Schlenk tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with imidazole (2.4
mmol), K2CO3 (4.2 mmol), CuI (0.16 mmol, 10 mol%), aryl halide (2.0
mmol), and PEG (3 mL). The tube was sealed after being evacuated twice
and back filled with N2. The mixture was stirred at 110°C for 24 h,
cooled to room temperature, and extracted with diethyl ether (5×10mL).
The upper layers were decanted, combined, and concentrated to the crude
product, which was analyzed by GC-MS. The PEG phase of the lower layer
was subjected to a second run with the same substrates. Further
purification of the product was achieved by flash chromatography on a
silica-gel column. All the products, which are known compounds, were
characterized and compared with authentic compounds previously reported
in the literatures.[9a,9b,12,15] 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole 1H NMR (300MHz,
CDCl3) δ 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.50-7.45 (m, 2H), 7.40-7.34 (m, 3H), 7.27 (s,
1H), 7.20 (s, 1H). GC-MS (EI, m/z): 144.0 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, optimized on copper catalyst,amount of
catalyst,base,polyethyleneglycol,atmosphere,temperature, reusable
catalyst, optimization study
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Efficient and Reusable Catalytic System of CuI-PEG for N-Arylation of
Imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Qiang; Luo, Jun; Wei, Yunyang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(1), 114-121

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for the Synthesis of N-Arylimidazole Derivatives. Under
an inert atmosphere, a 4-mL reaction vial was charged with K2CO3 (1
mmol), CuI or CuCl (2.5-5% mmol), HMTA (2.5-5% mmol), imidazole (0.6
mmol), and aryl halide (0.5 mmol). After it was sealed with a cap
containing a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) septum, 1mL of dry DMF was
injected by syringe. The reaction mixture was heated to 130-140°C for
20-40 h. The reaction was monitored by GC. After the starting material
was completely consumed, the reaction was stopped and the mixture was
cooled to room temperature. The reaction mixture was passed through a
plug of celite and rinsed with 10mL of ethyl acetate. The filtrate was
washed by 15mL of H2O. After the organic layer was concentrated, the
residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to give the
desired product.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, optimized on ligand,temperature,solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Cheap Cu(I)/Hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA) Catalytic System for C-N
Coupling Reactions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Cao, Changsheng; Lu, Zhongbo; Cai, Zhengyuan; Pang, Guangsheng; Shi,
Yanhui
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(2), 279-284

$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Arylation of
Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Halides. To a solution of CH3ONa
(3.0 mmol)in DMSO (3 mL) was added CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) and ligand (0.2
mmol). After stirring at room temperature for 30 min, a mixtureof halide
(2.0 mmol) and nitrogen-containing heterocycle (2.0mmol) in 2 mL of DMSO
was added to the flask, and the reaction mixture was stirred at the
indicated temperature for the corresponding reaction time. The mixture
was cooled to room temperature,10 mL of water was added, and the
resulting suspension was extracted with ethyl acetate (4 x 10 mL). The
extraction was dried over MgSO4, then concentrated and purified by column
chromatography on silica gel. Pale yellow oil, yield 96%. 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.27-8.26 (m, 1H), 8.20 (s, 1H), 7.63-7.61 (m, 1H), 7.48
(s, 1H), 7.17-7.15 (d, J= 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.05-7.02(m, 2H).13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 148.88, 138.88, 134.79, 130.35, 121.86, 116.03, 112.14.LRMS
(EI, 20 eV) m/z (%) 145 (M+, 100)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Hydroxyimides as Efficient Ligands for the Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation
of Pyrrole, Imidazole, and Indole
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Ma, Heng-Chang; Jiang, Xuan-Zhen
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(23), 8943-8946

$DATUM 14024-18-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the systhesis of diaryl
amines: A Schlenk tube equipped with a magnetic stir bar was charged with
p-toluidine (2a, 80 mg, 0.75 mmol), K2CO3 (138 mg, 1 mmol), Fe(acac) 3
(34.4 mg, 20% mol) and Cu(OAc)2·H2O (20 mg, 20% mol). Under a nitrogen
atmosphere, bromobenzene (1a, 0.5mmol, 78.0 mg) was added followed by dry
DMF (0.8 mL). The reaction mixture was then heated in an oil bath of
135°C. After being stirred at this temperature for 20 h, the mixture was
cooled to room temperature and diluted with diethyl ether. The resulting
suspension was directly filtered through a pad of celite and the filtrate
was concentrated and the crude mixtures were purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (300-400 mesh) using petroleum ether/ethyl
acetate solvent mixture as the eluent. 2-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyridine.
Yield: 95%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): 8.47 (d, J = 4.2Hz, 1H), 8.36 (s,
1H), 7.82 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (s, 1H), 7.36 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H),
7.25-7.22 (m, 1H), 7.12 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): 149.44, 139.33,
135.27, 130.98, 122.33, 116.45, 112.63. HRMS (EI+): calcd for C8H7N3
(M+): 145.0640, found 145.0639.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
2-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidine (3q)5 Following the general procedure,
white solid was obtained (97% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.10 (s,
1H), 7.14 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (s, 1H), 8.55 (s, 1H), 8.61 (d, J =
5.2 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 116.4, 118.7, 130.5, 136.0,
158.6 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 146 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple Copper Salt-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Guo, Peng; Li, Gaocan; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(22), 8535-8538

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 935547-42-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Aryl Halides. A
flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged
with CuI (9.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), ligand (0.1 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0
mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.0 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl
halide (1.2 mmol), and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced
with a glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back
filled with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room
temperature, and then heated to 110 °C for 24 h. The reaction mixture was
then cooled to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate,
filtered through a plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired
product. 1-Phenyl-1H-imidazole (7a) 2 2-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidine (7s)
5 Following the general procedure, imidazole (0.068 g, 1.0 mmol) was
coupled with 2-chloropyrimidine (137mg, 1.2 mmol) in the presence of
ligand 4a. The crude product was purified over a silica gel column using
ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give white solid (97% yield). 1H NMR
(400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.10 (s, 1H), 7.14 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (s, 1H),
8.55 (s, 1H), 8.61 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ
116.4,118.7, 130.5, 136.0, 158.6 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 146 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Efficient Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Cheng, Liang; Zhang, Yuxi; Xie, Rugang; You, Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(8), 2737-2743

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: N-tert-Butoxycarbonylation of Amines or Amine
Derivatives; General Procedure To a solution containing di-tert-butyl
dicarbonate (218 mg, 1 mmol) in HFIP (1 mL) was added the amine or amine
derivative (1 mmol) and the mixture was vigorously stirred at r.t.
Effervescence occurred immediately after the addition of the amine. The
products were isolated by filtration (for solid products) or after
selective evaporation of the HFIP (for liquid products) to yield the
highly pure N-Boc derivatives. Compound 3t, yield 97%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry (- process simplification), waste reduction, solvent was
recycled

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure. To a magnetically stirred
mixture of amine (1 mmol) and (Boc)2O (1 mmol) a catalytic amount of
iodine (10 mol %) was added under solvent-free conditions at room
temperature. After stirring the reaction mixture for the specified time
(Tables 2-4), diethyl ether (10 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was
washed with Na2S2O3 (5%, 5 mL) and saturated NaHCO3 and dried over
Na2SO4, the solvent was rotavaped under reduced pressure, and the residue
was purified by silica gel column chromatography (60-120, 5-15% EtOAc in
hexane) to afford the corresponding pure product. 18. tert-butyl
1H-1-imidazolecarboxylate (entry 20, Table 3): IR (neat): ν 3364, 2975,
2930, 1725, 1699, 1502, 1308, 1165, 1070, 1015 cm-1; 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 1.63 (s, 9H), 7.02 (s, 1H), 7.33 (s, 1H), 8.04 (s, 1H); 13C NMR
(75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 27.6, 85.6, 117.2, 130.3, 137.2, 147.4; EI-MS: 168
(M+); Analysis: C8H12N2O2 requires C: 57.13, H: 7.19, N: 16.66 found C:
57.11, H: 7.12, N: 16.69; A copy of the 1H NMR spectrum is provided.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with chloroarenes In a typical experimental procedure,
chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole (81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium
carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in
case of electron rich chloroarenes only) and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg)
were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for 36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst
was filtered and the filtrate was quenched with aqueous sodium hydrogen
carbonate and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined
organic extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered.
Solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and concentrated in vacuo
to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl acetate, 70/30) to afford the
N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1, entry 9,). The known coupling
products are well compared with the reported spectral data and melting
points. For the new compounds HRMS data are included.
1-(2-cyanophenyl)-1H-imidazole 12) 1-(2-cyanophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table
1, entry 12). 1H NMR (300MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 7.57 –7.32 (m, 3H), 7.27 – 7.12
(m, 2H), 7.02 (br s, 1H), 6.80 (br s, 1H); EIMS: 169(100 %), 142, 129,
115, 102, 75, 51; GC/MS: tR = 21.10 min; m/z : 169.10 IR: (KBr) cm-1;
2924.64, 2224.08, 1600.0, 1507.69, 1384.38, 1309, 1258.74, 1062.93,
825.17, 774.82.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, copper-exchanged fluorapatite used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Design and Evolution of Copper Apatite Catalysts for N-Arylation of
Heterocycles with Chloro- and Fluoroarenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Choudary, Boyapati M.; Sridhar, Chidara; Kantam, Mannepalli L.; Venkanna,
Gopaldasu T.; Sreedhar, Bojja
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127(28), 9948-9949

$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 1-Oligo(ethylene glycol) Monomethyl Ether
Imidazoles (2a-c). General Procedure. To a stirring solution of imidazole
(10.00 g, 147.0 mmol) in freshly distilled THF (300 mL) was added NaH (60
wt % in mineral oil; 7.35 g, 184 mmol). Hydrogen gas was observed to
bubble from the reaction mixture. The cloudy white solution was stirred
at 50 °C for 1 h. A tosylate (1a-c; 147 mmol) was added, and the solution
was heated to reflux. After 3 h, the brown solution was cooled to ambient
temperature and filtered. The THF solvent was evaporated, and the
resulting brown oil was dissolved in MeOH (100 mL) and washed with
hexanes (100 mL). Evaporation of the solvent gave a crude brown oil,
which was purified by filtration through a short column of silica gel
with 20:1 CH2Cl2/MeOH. The pure product as a clear light brown oil.
Typical yields were near 90%. 1-(2-(2-Methoxyethoxy)ethyl)-imidazole 2b.
Yield = 21.07 g, 97%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 3.37 (s, 3H), 3.52 (t,
2H), 3.56 (t, 2H), 3.74 (t, 2H), 4.12 (t, 2H), 6.99 (d, 1H), 7.04 (d,
1H), 7.54 (s, 1H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Enhanced CO2 Separation Selectivity in Oligo(ethylene glycol)
Functionalized Room-Temperature Ionic Liquids
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bara, Jason E.; Gabriel, Christopher J.; Lessmann, Sonja; Carlisle,
Trevor K.; Finotello, Alexia; Gin, Douglas L.; Noble, Richard D.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2007), 46(16), 5380-5386

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure To a solution of diazole (3 mmol) and aryl iodides (1
mmol) in xylene (3 mL) under argon atmosphere were added CuI (38 mg, 20
mol%) and 1,10-phenanthroline (40 mg, 20 mol%) followed by KF/Al2O320 (5
equiv, 780 mg) and stirred at 130-140 °C for specified times (Table 1).
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. The reaction mixture
allowed to cool to r.t. and was then partitioned between CH2Cl2 (30 mL)
and sat. aq NH4Cl (3 × 10 mL). The organic phase was washed with H2O (3 ×
10 mL), dried (Na2SO4), filtered and concentrated. The crude product was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel using hexane-EtOAc as
eluent (9:1). Table 1, entry 1, yield 97%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly efficient copper-catalyzed formation of N-aryl diazoles using
KF/Al2O3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Hosseinzadeh, Rahman; Tajbakhsh, Mahmood; Alikarami, Mohammad
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synlett (2006), (13), 2124-2126

$DATUM 534-17-8

$DATUM 906640-61-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for Cu(I)-Catalyzed Coupling Reactions of Phenyl Halide
with Imidazole. CuI/1,10-Phenanthroline asthe Catalyst. A 50 mL
oven-dried Schlenk tube containing a stirbar was quickly charged with CuI
(0.019 g, 0.10 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (1,10-phen) (0.036 g, 0.20
mmol), imidazole (0.068g, 1.0 mmol), and the base Cs2CO3 (0.650 g, 2.0
mmol). The tubewas sealed and evacuated and refilled with N2. Predried
phenylhalide (1.0 mL), after being bubbled with N2, was transferred
intothe Schlenk tube via syringe. The mixture was heated in an oilbath
under appropriate temperature for 19 or 48 h. After beingcooled to room
temperature, the reaction mixture was diluted with20 mL of water and was
extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 x20 mL). After the solvent was removed, the
residue was purified by chromatographyon a silica gel column with ethyl
acetate/hexanes (4:1) as the eluent. yield 75%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM A total of 1.0 mmol of iodobenzene, 1.2 mmol of imidazole, 2.0 mmol of
base, and 5.0 mg of catalyst were placed in the reaction vessel. Then, 2
mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was added with the protection of
nitrogen. The reaction mixture was heated fast to 110 °C in an oil bath
and kept at this temperature for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature,
the reaction mixture was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC). Final
product, Yield: 95.8%. catalyst: Phe-G-Cu, amino acid: L-phenylalanine,
loading of Cu: 8.3 wt%, NaOH (2 mmol).

type reaction, using NaOH as base gave similar yield (95%) and catalyst
could be recycled twice giving slightly lower yield, alternative
preparation shown, optimization study, optimized on reagent

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for Copper-Catalyzed
N-Arylations of Azoles with Aryl Halides (Table 4) Under an atmosphere of
argon, aryl halide (1.5 mmol) was added to the mixture of azole (1 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (2 mmol), ligand (0.10 mmol), and CuI (0.05 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) at
r.t. The mixture was stirred at 110 °C. After 24 h, the mixture was
cooled to r.t., diluted with EtOAc, and filtered through Celite, eluting
with additional EtOAc. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced
pressure, and the resulting residue was purified by silica gel
chromatography using a mixture of hexane and EtOAc to provide the desired
product. All prepared compounds 3 except for 3j were known and identified
by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and MS. Table 4, entry 16, 3q, yield 96%.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure B: Coupling of Aryl halides
with Amides, Imidazoles, Phenols or Thiols. (Table 2, entry 4): An
oven-dried Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon valve was charged with a
magnetic stir bar, Cs2CO3 (684 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuBr (15 mg, 0.10 mmol, 10
mol%), and ethyl 2-oxocyclohexanecarboxylate (34 mg, 0.20 mmol, 20 mol%)
The tube was evacuated and backfilled with N2 (this procedure was
repeated three times). Under a counter flow of N2, DMSO (0.5 mL) was
added by syringe at room temperature (25-30 °C) and pre-stirred for 0.5
h. Then a solution of 1-iodo-4-methylbenzene (218 mg, 1.0 mmol),
2-pyrrolidinone (102 mg, 1.2 mmol) in DMSO (0.5 mL) was added via syringe
under a counter flow of N2. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 60 ºC. The reaction mixture was directly
passed through celite. After rinsed with further 60 mL of ethyl acetate,
the combined filtrate was washed by saturated brine (10 ml × 2). After
the organic layer was dried by Na2SO4, it was concentrated by rotatory
evaporation. The residue was purified bycolumn chromatography on silica
gel using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:1) as eluent to give a white solid of
1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one (151 mg, 86 %). 1d, 1-p-tolylpyrrolidin-2-one4
(Table 2, entry 4, 10) 2a, 1-phenyl-1H-imidazole1 (Table 3, entries 1 and
5) Procedure B was followed. Slightly yellow oil; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3)
δ 7.79 (1 H, s), 7.38-7.42 (2 H, m), 7.27-7.32 (3 H, m), 7.21 (1 H, s),
7.15 (1 H, s) (TMS δ -0.05); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 137.2, 135.4,
130.3, 129.7, 127.3, 121.3, 118.1 (CDCl3 δ 77.0).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7778-53-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: GENERAL SYNTHETIC PROCEDURE N-Heterocycles (1
mmol) and α ,β -unsaturated carbonyl compounds (1.2 mmol) were added to a
10-mL flask containing anhydrous K3PO4 (0.25 mmol), and the mixture was
stirred at room temperature for a period of time. The reaction mixture
was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure. The
residue was purified by flash-column chromatography (silica gel,
petroleum ether-ethyl acetate) to obtain the corresponding Michael
adducts. All compounds can be stored at rt for several months without
decomposition. 3-Imidazole-1-yl-propionic Acid Ethyl Ester (3b) Yellow
oil. Yield 95%. 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3): δ = 1.245 (t, 3H, J=7.6 Hz),
2.769 (t, 2H, J=6.2 Hz), 4.162 (d, d, 2H, J=7.2 Hz, 14.4 Hz), 4.271 (t,
2H, J=6.6 Hz), 6.935 (s, 1H), 7.050 (s, 1H), 7.511 (s, 1H). ESI-MS:
m/z=169 (M+1).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, Michael addition
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild and efficient procedure for Michael addition of N-heterocycles to
α,β-unsaturated compounds using anhydrous K3PO4 as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Hou, Xueling; Hemit, Helimay; Yong, Jianping; Nie, Lifei; Aisa, Haji
Akber
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2010), 40(7), 973-979

$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM An oven-dried 100 mL round-bottomed flask with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (1 mol, 19 mg), K2CO3 (12 mmol, 1.66 g), substituted
1H-imidazole or 1H-benzo[d]imidazole (12 mmol), substituted
1-fluoro-2-nitrobenzene (10 mmol), and DMF (10 mL) under nitrogen. The
mixture was stirred for 24 h at 110 °C. The resulting solution was then
cooled to room temperature and filtered. The solid was washed with ethyl
acetate for three times (3 x 10 mL), and the combined filtrate was
concentrated by the rotary evaporator, and the residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate
(1:1) as eluent to give I. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Copper-Catalyzed Aerobic Oxidative Intramolecular C-H Amination Leading
to Imidazobenzimidazole Derivatives
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Wang, Xiaoqiang; Jin, Yunhe; Zhao, Yufen; Zhu, Lin; Fu, Hua
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2012), 14(2), 452-455

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 584-08-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1017605-84-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure of N-Arylation
Under Homogeneous Conditions Catalyst 1f (0.007 g, 1 mol%), K2CO3 (0.276
g, 2 mmol) were added to a mixture of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.158 g, 1
mmol) and imidazole (0.081 g, 1.2 mmol) in 3 mL of DMF. The reaction
mixture was heated at 110 °C under stirring for 1.5 h. After cooling to
ambient temperature, the resulting mixture was added with 4 mL of ethyl
acetate and 10 mL of water. The organic layer was separated, and the
aqueous layer was further extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The
combined organic phase was washed with brine and dried over Na2SO4. The
solvent was removed under vacuum, and the residue was further purified by
flash-column chromatography on silica gel to afford the product
1-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole in 94% yield. Table 4, Entry 5, yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Arylation of heterocycles with chloro- and fluoroarenes using
resin-supported sulfonato-Cu(salen) complex
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kantam, M. Lakshmi; Ramani, T.; Chakrapani, L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(4), 626-636

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME26 STEP1
$RXN

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A typical procedure for N-arylation of
imidazole with chloroarenes In a typical experimental procedure,
chlorobenzene (0.1 mL, 1 mmol), imidazole (81 mg, 1.2 mmol), potassium
carbonate (276 mg, 2 mmol), potassium tert-butoxide (11 mg, 10 mol% in
case of electron rich chloroarenes only) and the catalyst (CuFAP, 100 mg)
were stirred in DMF (4 mL) at 120°C for 36 h. After 36 h, the catalyst
was filtered and the filtrate was quenched with aqueous sodium hydrogen
carbonate and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined
organic extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered.
Solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and concentrated in vacuo
to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (hexane/ethyl acetate, 70/30) to afford the
N-phenylimidazole (115 mg, 80%, Table1, entry 9,). The known coupling
products are well compared with the reported spectral data and melting
points. For the new compounds HRMS data are included.
1-(4-Cyanophenyl)-1H-imidazole 3) 1-(4-Cyanophenyl)-1H-imidazole (Table
1, entry 3). 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): δ= 7.90 (br s, 1H), 7.79 (d, 2H, J=
8.3 Hz), 7.53 (d, 2H, J = 8.3 Hz), 7.29 (br s, 1H), 7.22 (br s, 1H); EI
MS: 169 (100%), 142, 115, 102, 75, 50; GC/MS: tR = 22.11 min; m/z :
169.20 IR: (KBr) cm-1 2923.75, 2226.63, 1609.35, 1521.97, 1304.78,
1057.90, 835.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, copper-exchanged fluorapatite used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Design and Evolution of Copper Apatite Catalysts for N-Arylation of
Heterocycles with Chloro- and Fluoroarenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Choudary, Boyapati M.; Sridhar, Chidara; Kantam, Mannepalli L.; Venkanna,
Gopaldasu T.; Sreedhar, Bojja
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127(28), 9948-9949

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN

$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Arylation of
Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles with Halides. To a solution of CH3ONa
(3.0 mmol)in DMSO (3 mL) was added CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) and ligand (0.2
mmol). After stirring at room temperature for 30 min, a mixtureof halide
(2.0 mmol) and nitrogen-containing heterocycle (2.0mmol) in 2 mL of DMSO
was added to the flask, and the reaction mixture was stirred at the
indicated temperature for the corresponding reaction time. The mixture
was cooled to room temperature,10 mL of water was added, and the
resulting suspension was extracted with ethyl acetate (4 x 10 mL). The
extraction was dried over MgSO4, then concentrated and purified by column
chromatography on silica gel. Yield 98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
7.79(s, 1H.), 7.42-7.39 (m, 2H), 7.30-7.27 (m, 2H), 7.21 (s, 1H), 7.17
(s, 1H).13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 135.77, 135.39, 133.04, 130.60,
129.90, 122.56, 118.03.LRMS (EI, 20 eV) m/z (%) 178 (M+, 100)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM N-Hydroxyimides as Efficient Ligands for the Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation
of Pyrrole, Imidazole, and Indole
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Ma, Heng-Chang; Jiang, Xuan-Zhen
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(23), 8943-8946

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure for the
Conjugate Addition of Imidazole to α ,β -Unsaturated Compounds: In a
typical procedure, α ,β-unsaturated compound (1.0 mmol), imidazole (1.0
mmol) and catalyst (3.6 mol%) were taken in toluene (5 mL) and stirred at
reflux temperature for 12 h. The resulting reaction mixture was filtered
and washed with EtOAc (3 × 5 mL) and concentrated under reduced pressure.
The crude product was purified by column chromatography to afford the
pure product. All the products gave satisfactory NMR data and mass
spectral data.12a,29 Table 2 Entry 2, yield 98%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM 7778-53-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM GENERAL SYNTHETIC PROCEDURE N-Heterocycles (1 mmol) and α ,β -unsaturated
carbonyl compounds (1.2 mmol) were added to a 10-mL flask containing
anhydrous K3PO4 (0.25 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room
temperature for a period of time. The reaction mixture was filtered, and
the filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue was
purified by flash-column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum
ether-ethyl acetate) to obtain the corresponding Michael adducts. All
compounds can be stored at rt for several months without decomposition.
3-Imidazole-1-yl-propionic Acid Methyl Ester (3a) Yellow oil. Yield 97%.
1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3): δ = 2.750 (t, 2H, J=6.8 Hz), 3.660 (s, 3H), 4.237
(t, 2H, J=6.6 Hz), 6.900 (s, 1H), 7.008 (s, 1H), 7.475 (s, 1H). ESI-MS:
m/z =155 (M+1).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, Michael addition, optimization study (optimized on amount
of catalyst)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild and efficient procedure for Michael addition of N-heterocycles to
α,β-unsaturated compounds using anhydrous K3PO4 as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Hou, Xueling; Hemit, Helimay; Yong, Jianping; Nie, Lifei; Aisa, Haji
Akber
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2010), 40(7), 973-979

$DATUM polystyrene-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl
Halides. A flamedried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was
charged with CuI (9.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), 4a-2 (145 mg, 0.1 mmol of the
L-proline unit), K2CO3 (165 mg, 1.2 mmol), nitrogen-containing
heterocycle (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide (0.6 mmol), and DMSO (2
mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the
system was then evacuated three times and backfilled with N2. The
reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then
heated at 120 °C for 60 h. The resulting mixture was cooled to ambient
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a
plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl acetate. The
filtrate was concentrated, and the resulting residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired product.
1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (6a)1 Following the general procedure,
imidazole (0.034 g, 0.5 mmol) was coupled with 4-bromoanisole (75 µL, 0.6
mmol). The crude product was purified over a silica gel column using
ethyl acetate/petrol ether (1/1) to give a white solid (97% yield). 1H
NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 3.86 (s, 3H), 6.99 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.20 (bs,
1H), 7.22 (bs, 1H), 7.30 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.79 (bs, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR
(150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 55.6, 114.8, 118.7, 123.18, 130.0, 130.7, 135.8,
158.9 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 174 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst (polymer-supported ionic liq.-copper complex),
optimized on polymer-supported ionic liq., solvent, base
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Concept of Supported Amino Acid Ionic Liquids and Their Application in

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for Coupling Reaction of
Aryl Halides with Pyrazole, Imidazole, or Benzimidazole Catalyzed by CuI
and Amino Acid. A resealable tube was charged with CuI (0.2 mmol),
L-proline or N,N-dimethylglycine (0.4 mmol), K2CO3 (4 mmol), aryl halide
(2.2 mmol), and azole (2 mmol), evacuated, and backfilled with nitrogen.
To this mixture was added 3 mL of DMSO by syringe at room temperature
under nitrogen. The mixture was heated at indicated temperature before it
was partitioned between water and ethyl acetate. The organic layer was
separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate. The
combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and
concentrated in vacuo. The residual oil was loaded on a silica gel column
and eluted with 1/10 to 1/ 8 ethyl acetate/petroleumether. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Amino Acid Promoted CuI-Catalyzed C-N Bond Formation between Aryl Halides
and Amines or N-Containing Heterocycles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Hui; Cai, Qian; Ma, Dawei
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2005), 70(13), 5164-5173

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 92149-07-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 872-50-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl bromides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.05 mmol), L1c (0.15 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol),
aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg),
Cs2CO3 (1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was
fitted with a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled
with argon or nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional
time. Aryl bromide (1.00 mmol, if liquid), and solvent (0.5 mL) were then
added successively. The reaction tube was sealed, immersed, and stirred
in a preheated oil bath for the designated time period. The reaction
mixture was cooled to room temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10
mL), filtered through a plug of celite, and eluted with additional
dichloromethane (50 mL). The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting
residue was purified by flash chromatography to provide the desired
product. 1-(4-tert-Butyl-phenyl)-1H-imidazole14 (2a)
1,4-bis(Imidazol-1-yl)-benzene20 (2h) The general procedure was followed
using Cu2O (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), L1c (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.90 g,
2.8 mmol), 1,4-dibromobenzene (236 mg, 1.00 mmol), and imidazole (164 mg,
2.4 mmol) with NMP (0.5 mL) as solvent for 30 h at 110 °C. The crude
reaction mixture was diluted in excess CH2Cl2, and filtered through a
celite plug. After removal of the solvent in vacuo, the product was
crystallized from EtOAc and stored in a freezer at -23 °C overnight, to
afford 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene (white solid, 200 mg, 95%). 1H NMR
(500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.90 (bs, 2H), 7.54 (s,4H), 7.32 (bs, 1H), 7.26 (bs,
1H). m.p. 190 °C (dec.). IR (KBr disc, cm-1) 1534, 1485, 1304, 1248,
1105, 1059. Anal Calc. for C12H10N4: C 68.56, H 4.79. Found C 68.49, H
4.90.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles and Benzimidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Koval, Erica D.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(16), 6190-6199

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the N-arylation of
imidazoles with aryl bromides. An oven-dried screw-cap test tube was
charged with Cu2O (0.05 mmol), L (0.15 mmol), imidazole (1.2 mmol), aryl
bromide (1.00 mmol, if solid), poly(ethylene glycol) (200 mg), Cs2CO3
(1.4 mmol), and a magnetic stir bar. The reaction vessel was fitted with
a rubber septum. The vessel was evacuated and back-filled with argon or
nitrogen, and this sequence was repeated an additional time. Aryl bromide
(1.00 mmol, if liquid), and solvent (0.5 mL) were then added
successively. The reaction tube was sealed, immersed, and stirred in a
preheated oil bath for the designated time period. The reaction mixture
was cooled to room temperature, diluted with dichloromethane (10 mL),
filtered through a plug of celite, and eluted with additional
dichloromethane (50 mL). The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting
residue was purified by flash chromatography to provide the desired
product. Experimental procedures for the N-arylation of imidazole with
aryl bromides. 4-Imidazol-1-yl-phenol 1,4-bis(Imidazol-1-yl)-benzene14
The general procedure was followed using Cu2O (7.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), L (36
mg, 0.15 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.90 g, 2.8 mmol), 1,4-dibromobenzene (236 mg,
1.00 mmol), and imidazole (164 mg, 2.4 mmol) with NMP (0.5 mL) as solvent
for 30 h at 110 °C. The crude reaction mixture was diluted in excess
CH2Cl2, and filtered through a celite plug. After removal of the solvent
in vacuo, the product was crystallized from EtOAc and stored in a freezer
overnight, to afford 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene (white solid, 200 mg,
95 %). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.90 (bs, 2H), 7.54 (s, 4H), 7.32 (bs,
1H), 7.26 (bs, 1H). m.p. 190 °C (decomp.). IR (KBr disc, cm-1) 1534,
1485, 1304, 1248, 1105, 1059. Anal Calc. for C12H10N4: C 68.56, H 4.79.
Found C 68.49, H 4.90.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 4,7-Dimethoxy-1,10-phenanthroline: An excellent ligand for the
Cu-catalyzed N-arylation of imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Altman, Ryan A.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2006), 8(13), 2779-2782

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of Endo-N-(9-Methyl-9-azabicyclo[3.3.1]non-3-yl)-2-amino
benzoxazole-4-carboxamide Hydrochloride. Step A: To a solution of
imidazole (13.63 g, 200 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (750 mL) was added cyanogen
bromide at room temperature and the resulting mixture was heated to
reflux for 45 min. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature
and the solid obtained was isolated by filtration. The filtrate was
concentrated to afford di(1H-imidazole-1-yl)methanimine as a white solid
(10.5 g, 97%). 1H NMR and MS consistent.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

other disease

$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole
with Aryl Bromides. A Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are
charged with a magnetic stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg,
0.20 mmol, 20 mol %), and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08
mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1 mL) was added at room temperature. Then a
solution of bromobenzene (188 mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0
mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture after completion of the reaction. Then it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as
eluant, to give an oil of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%)
1-p-Tolyl-1H-imidazole (4b), yield 96% 1H NMR (300 MHz): 7.81 (s, 1H),
7.27-7.18 ( m, 6H), 2.39 (s, 3H) 13C NMR (75 MHz): 137.4, 135.5, 134.8,
130.3, 130.0, 121.3, 118.3, 20.90 GC-MS: m/z 157.8 (M+)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host
for Cu(I)-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Suresh, Palaniswamy; Pitchumani, Kasi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73(22), 9121-9124

$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: In an oven dried 100 mL RB flask, Cu-PAR (0.05
g, 0.0129 mmol), aryl halide (1 mmol), N-H heterocycles (1.2 mmol), K2CO3
(2 mmol), and 10 mL DMSO were stirred under nitrogen atmosphere, at 100
°C. The reaction mixtures were collected at different time interval and
identified by GCMS and quantified by GC analysis. After the completion of
the reaction, the catalyst was filtered off and washed with water
followed by acetone and dried in oven. The filtrate was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 by vacuum. The filtrate was con- centrated by vacuum and
the resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel
to provide the desired product.
1-(4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)ethanone(D). Time (h): 10, Isolated Yield
(%): 96. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.08 (d, 2H), 7.95 (bs, 1H), 7.49
(d,2H), 7.35 (bs, 1H), 7.24 (bs, 1H), 2.63 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 196.4, 140.7, 135.7, 135.4, 131.0,130.3, 120.6, 117.7, 26.5.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, catalyst prepared and used, chloromethylated
polystyrene-supported copper(II) 4-(2-pyridylazo)resorcinol complex
catalyst used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM An Efficient Recyclable Polymer Supported Copper(II) Catalyst for C-N
Bond Formation by N-Arylation

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Coupling of Aryl Iodides with Amines at Room
Temperature; General Procedure An oven-dried Schlenk tube was charged
with CuI (20 mg, 10 mol%), Cs2CO3 (652 mg, 2 mmol), and 3-acetylcoumarin
(L5, 38 mg, 20 mol%). The tube was evacuated and backfilled with N2 (this
procedure was repeated 3 ×). Then aryl halide (1.0 mmol), amine (1.5
mmol), and DMF (0.5 mL) were added under N2. The tube was sealed and the
mixture was stirred at r.t. for 24 h. The resulting suspension was
filtered through a pad of silica gel with the help of CH2Cl2 (50 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated and the residue was purified by column
chromatography (silica gel, EtOAc-PE). The product.
1-[4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]ethanone (3r). IR (KBr): 3116, 1679, 1608,
1520, 1492, 1426, 1363, 1307, 1252, 1189, 1111, 1060, 956, 820 cm-1. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.09 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2 H), 7.96 (s, 1 H), 7.50
(d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2 H), 7.36 (s, 1 H), 7.25 (s, 1 H), 2.64 (s, 3 H). 13C
NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 196.6, 140.9, 136.0, 135.5, 131.3, 130.5,
120.9, 117.9, 26.7. GC-MS (EI): m/z = 186.04 [M]+. HRMS (EI): m/z [M]+
calcd for C11H10N2O: 186.0793; found: 186.0788.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 3-Acetylcoumarin as a practical ligand for copper-catalyzed C-N coupling
reactions at room temperature
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tao, Chuan-Zhou; Liu, Wei-Wei; Sun, Ji-You; Cao, Zhi-Ling; Li, Hui;
Zhang, Ying-Fen
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2010), (8), 1280-1284

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 25322-68-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling Reaction A
Schlenk tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with imidazole (2.4
mmol), K2CO3 (4.2 mmol), CuI (0.16 mmol, 10 mol%), aryl halide (2.0
mmol), and PEG (3 mL). The tube was sealed after being evacuated twice
and back filled with N2. The mixture was stirred at 110°C for 24 h,
cooled to room temperature, and extracted with diethyl ether (5×10mL).
The upper layers were decanted, combined, and concentrated to the crude
product, which was analyzed by GC-MS. The PEG phase of the lower layer
was subjected to a second run with the same substrates. Further
purification of the product was achieved by flash chromatography on a
silica-gel column. All the products, which are known compounds, were
characterized and compared with authentic compounds previously reported
in the literatures.[9a,9b,12,15] Entry 1; Yield 96%.
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.38 (d, 2H, J =
9.0 Hz), 8.01 (s, 1H), 7.60 (d, 2H, J = 9.0 Hz), 7.41 (s, 1H), 7.31 (s,
1H). GC-MS (EI, m/z): 188.9 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, alternative preparation shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Efficient and Reusable Catalytic System of CuI-PEG for N-Arylation of
Imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Qiang; Luo, Jun; Wei, Yunyang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2012), 42(1), 114-121

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7787-70-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Procedure for the
Solvent-Free Copper- Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazoles. A mixture of
imidazole 1 (1.0 mmol), aryl halide 2 (1.2 mmol), CuBr (10 mol %),
2-aminopyrimidine-4,6-diol (L1, 20 mol %), and TBAF (3 mmol) was stirred
at 145-150 °C for 24 h until complete consumption of starting material
was monitored by TLC. After the reaction was finished, ethyl acetate was
poured into the mixture, then washed with water, extracted with diethyl
ether, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and evaporated under vacuum, and the
residue was purified by flash column chromatography (ethyl acetate or
hexane/ethyl acetate) to afford the desired product.
1-(4-Nitrophenyl)-1H-imidazole (4) Slight yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz,
CDCl3) δ: 8.40 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 8.01 (s, 1H), 7.60 (d, J = 9.0 Hz,
2H), 7.40 (s, 1H), 7.29 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ:
146.5, 142.0, 135.4, 131.8, 125.7, 121.1, 117.6; LRMS (EI, 20 eV) m/z
(%): 189 (M+, 100).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM 2-Aminopyrimidine-4,6-diol as an efficient ligand for solvent-free
copper-catalyzed N-arylations of imidazoles with aryl and heteroaryl
halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Xie, Ye-Xiang; Pi, Shao-Feng; Wang, Jian; Yin, Du-Lin; Li, Jin-Heng
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71(21), 8324-8327

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure. A flame-dried Schlenk test
tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with CuI (38.4 mg, 0.2
mmol), K3PO4 (0.422 g, 2.0 mmol), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4
mmol), aryl halide (1.0 mmol), and DMF (1 mL) under N2 atmosphere. A
rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the system was then
evacuated twice and back filled with N2. After being stirred at 35-40 °C
for 40 h, the reaction mixture was diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate,
filtered through a plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The filtrate was concentrated and the resulting residue was
purified by column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired
product. N-(4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)acetamide (3k) Following the
general procedure, the crude product was purified over a silica gel
column using ethyl acetate to give a white solid (98% yield). 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.21 (s, 3H), 7.22 (bs, 1H), 7.26 (bs, 1H), 7.32 (d, J =
8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.65 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.83 (bs, 1H), 8.15 (bs, 1H) ppm.
GC-MS (EI, m/z): 201.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Functional Group Tolerance in Copper-Catalyzed N-Arylation of
Nitrogen-Containing Heterocycles under Mild Conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Li, Gaocan; Luo, Liang; Guo, Peng; Lan, Jingbo; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(5), 2200-2202

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: II. General procedure for the catalytic
N-arylation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with aryl or heteroaryl
halides To a flame-dried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar
was charged with CuI (38.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cs2CO3 (0.652 g, 2.0 mmol),
nitrogen-containing heterocycle (1.4 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide
(1.0 mmol) and DMF (2 mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a
glass stopper, and the system was then evacuated twice and back filled
with N2. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature,
and then heated at 120 °C for 40 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled
to ambient temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered
through a plug of silica gel, and and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic extracts were concentrated and the
resulting residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to
provide the desired product. 1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole (3a)2
4-Imidazol-1-yl-benzonitrile (3d)2 Following the general procedure, a
white solid was obtained (98% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.31 (s,
1H), 7.41 (s, 1H), 7.57 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 8.04 (s, 1H), 8.37 (d, J =
8.8 Hz, 2H) ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 110.9, 117.5, 117.8, 121.3,
131.4, 134.1, 135.2, 140.4 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 169 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Simple Copper Salt-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Nitrogen-Containing
Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl Halides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhu, Liangbo; Guo, Peng; Li, Gaocan; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 72(22), 8535-8538

$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM [0336] 1-(3-Phenylpropyl)-1H-imidazole hydrochloride (QC-172). Under an
atmosphere of N2, a mixture of imidazole (376 mg, 5.52 mmol, 1.1 equiv)
and sodium hydroxide (221 mg, 5.52 mmol, 1.1 equiv) in DMSO (2 mL) was
heated at70-80°C with stirring for 1.5 h. To this mixture was added a
solution of 1-bromo-3-phenylpropane (1.00 g, 5.02 mmol, 1 equiv) in DMSO
(2 mL) and the mixture heated at70-80°C with stirring for 13 h, heating
was slightly elevated and the DMSO was removed by blowing a stream of air
over the reaction mixture. High-vacuum drying left a yellow residue.
After dilution with H2O, the mixture was extracted with benzene (3×50 mL)
and the combined organic extracts were washed with brine (2×), dried
(MgSO4) and concentrated to give the free base of QC-172. (914 mg, 4.91
mmol, 98%).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DATUM Under an atmosphere of N2. a mixture of imidazole (376 mg, 5.52 mmol, 1.1
equiv) and sodium hydroxide (221 mg, 5.52 mmol, 1.1 equiv) in DMSO (2 mL)
was heated at 70-80°C with stirring for 1.5 h. To this mixture was added
a solution of 1-bromo-3-phenyl propane (1.00 g, 5.02 mmol, 1 equiv) in
DMSO (2 mL), and the mixture heated at 70-80°C with stirring for 13 h.
Heating was slightly elevated and the DMSO was removed by blowing a
stream of air over the reaction mixture. High-vacuum drying left a yellow
residue. After dilution with H2O, the mixture was extracted with benzene
(3 x 50 mL) and the combined organic extracts were washed with brine (2
x), dried (MgSO4), and concentrated to give the free base (914 mg, 4.91
mmol, 98%).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole
with Aryl Bromides. A Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are
charged with a magnetic stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg,
0.20 mmol, 20 mol %), and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08
mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1 mL) was added at room temperature. Then a
solution of bromobenzene (188 mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0
mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture after completion of the reaction. Then it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as
eluant, to give an oil of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%)
3-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (4i), yield 98% 1H NMR (400 MHz): 7.90
(s, 1H), 7.83-7.42 (m, 4H), 7.31 (bs, 1H), 7.27 (bs, 1H) 13C NMR (100
MHz): 138.0, 135.4, 131.3, 131.0, 128.5, 127.3, 125.5, 124.5, 117.4,
114.3 GC-MS: m/z 168.9 (M+)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host
for Cu(I)-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Suresh, Palaniswamy; Pitchumani, Kasi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73(22), 9121-9124

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 2.9. Synthesis of IMS-UDImBr. 1-(10-Undecen-1-yl)-1H-imidazole 7 (UDIm)
was prepared as per literature precedent. NaOH (12.50 g, 312.5 mmol) was
dissolved in water (12.50 g) and mixed with THF (60 mL). Imidazole (1.31
g, 19.8 mmol) and TBAB (0.606 g, 1.98 mmol) were added to the solution at
25 °C until all the solids were dissolved, prior to adding
11-bromo-1-undecene (4.35 g, 18.64 mmol) and heating to 60 °C for 16 h.
Upon cooling, the THF was removed by rotary evaporation, and the product
was extracted three times with DCM. The organic layer was dried with
magnesium sulfate, and the filtrate was concentrated by rotary
evaporation. 1-(10-undecen-1-yl)-1H-imidazole. Pale yellow oil, 98%
yield. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.40 (s, 1H, -N-CH-N-), δ 7.00 (s, 1H,
-N-CH═CH-N-), δ 6.85 (s, 1H, -N-CH═CH-N-), δ 5.75 (ddt, 1H, -CH2-CH═CH2),
δ 4.90 (dd, 2H, -CH2-CH═CH2), δ 3.86 (t, 2H), δ 1.98 (dd, 2H), δ 1.71 (t,
2H), δ 1.22-1.32 (m, 12H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Poly(isobutylene-co-para-methylstyrene): Synthesis of Peroxide-Curable
Ionomeric Elastomers
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Dakin, Jackson M.; Whitney, Ralph A.; Parent, J. Scott
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2014), 53(45), 17527-17536

$DATUM Biological based (nano) gelatoric ionic liquids (NGILs) Synthesis and

$DATUM 7778-53-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: GENERAL SYNTHETIC PROCEDURE N-Heterocycles (1
mmol) and α ,β -unsaturated carbonyl compounds (1.2 mmol) were added to a
10-mL flask containing anhydrous K3PO4 (0.25 mmol), and the mixture was
stirred at room temperature for a period of time. The reaction mixture
was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure. The
residue was purified by flash-column chromatography (silica gel,
petroleum ether-ethyl acetate) to obtain the corresponding Michael
adducts. All compounds can be stored at rt for several months without
decomposition. 3-Imidazole-1-yl-propionamide (3e) White solid; Yield 98%.
mp 139-140°C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO): δ = 2.52 (t, 2H, J=6.8 Hz), 4.151
(t, 2H, J=6.8 Hz), 6.846 (t, 1H, J=1.2 Hz), 6.922 (s, 1H), 7.108 (t, 1H,
J=1.2 Hz), 7.377 (s, 1H), 7.558 (s, 1H). ESI-MS: m/z=140 (M+1).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, Michael addition
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Mild and efficient procedure for Michael addition of N-heterocycles to
α,β-unsaturated compounds using anhydrous K3PO4 as catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Hou, Xueling; Hemit, Helimay; Yong, Jianping; Nie, Lifei; Aisa, Haji
Akber
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2010), 40(7), 973-979

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-081-CAS-7289175
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 96
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for preparation of compounds 4 and 5. Imidazole (0.47
mol, 31 g), or 2-methylimidazole (0.47 mol, 38.55 g) was suspended in dry
dichloromethane (400 mL) and cooled to 0 °C in an ice bath.
Benzenesulfonyl chloride (0.157 mol, 27.64 g, 20 mL) was added dropwise
via a syringe over 15 min. during the addition all the imidazole
dissolves and in the case of compound 4 a white precipitate starts to
appear. The reaction mixture was the stirred at room temperature for 5
hours. For compound 4, the mixture was filtered and the filter cake was
washed with dichloromethane. The filtrate was washed with brine (2x) and
water (1x). In the case of compound 5, the 2-methylimidazolium
hydrochloride by-product did not precipitate out during the reaction so
the filtration step was omitted. The organic layer was concentrated and
the crude product recrystallized from ethylacetate-hexane to give a white
crystals. Compound 4 was obtained. Its 1H-NMR was identical to that
previously reported.1 Yield 31.4 g, 96%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Sulfonyl Imidazolium Salts as Reagents for the Rapid and Efficient
Synthesis of Nucleoside Polyphosphates and Their Conjugates
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Mohamady, Samy; Desoky, Ahmed; Taylor, Scott D.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2012), 14(1), 402-405

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME71 STEP1

$DATUM 30754-24-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for N-Arylation of Imidazole
with Aryl Bromides. A Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock are
charged with a magnetic stir bar, K2CO3 (572 mg, 2.1 mmol), CuI (0.38 mg,
0.20 mmol, 20 mol %), and per-6-amino- β -cyclodextrin (100 mg, 0.08
mmol, 8 mol %). DMSO (1 mL) was added at room temperature. Then a
solution of bromobenzene (188 mg, 1.2 mmol) and imidazole (68 mg, 1.0
mmol) in DMSO (1 mL) was added. The tube was sealed and the mixture was
allowed to stir for 24 h at 110°C. Water (5 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture after completion of the reaction. Then it was extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL) and the combined organic layers were dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by vacuum. The residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel, using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:3) as
eluant, to give an oil of 1-phenylimidazole 4a (164 mg, 98%)
1-(Thiophen-3-yl)-1H-imidazole (4q), yield 97% 1H NMR (300 MHz): 7.99
(bs, 1H), 7.44 (m, 1H), 7.31- 7.19 (m, 4H) 13C NMR (75 MHz): 136.2,
135.7, 129.8, 127.1, 121.2, 118.4, 113.0 GC-MS: m/z 150.0 (M+)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used, Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin as an Efficient Supramolecular Ligand and Host
for Cu(I)-Catalyzed N-Arylation of Imidazole with Aryl Bromides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Suresh, Palaniswamy; Pitchumani, Kasi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2008), 73(22), 9121-9124

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME86 STEP1

$DATUM reaction products with sodium hydroxide and L-proline
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 960243-04-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(3):AMD
$DATUM polystyrene-supported
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Catalytic
N-Arylation of Nitrogen- Containing Heterocycles with Aryl and Heteroaryl
Halides. A flamedried Schlenk test tube with a magnetic stirring bar was
charged with CuI (9.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), 4a-2 (145 mg, 0.1 mmol of the
L-proline unit), K2CO3 (165 mg, 1.2 mmol), nitrogen-containing
heterocycle (0.5 mmol), aryl or heteroaryl halide (0.6 mmol), and DMSO (2
mL) under N2. A rubber septum was replaced with a glass stopper, and the
system was then evacuated three times and backfilled with N2. The
reaction mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then
heated at 120 °C for 60 h. The resulting mixture was cooled to ambient
temperature, diluted with 2-3 mL of ethyl acetate, filtered through a
plug of silica gel, and washed with 10-20 mL of ethyl acetate. The
filtrate was concentrated, and the resulting residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel to provide the desired product.
4-Imidazol-1-ylphenol (6j)3 Following the general procedure, imidazole
(0.034 g, 0.5 mmol) was coupled with 4-bromophenol (0.104 g, 0.6 mmol).
The crude reaction mixture was dissolved in 10 mL of 2 M HCl, and washed
once with diethyl ether. The aqueous layer was brought to pH =8 with
Na2CO3, and extracted repeatedly with CH2Cl2. The combined organic layer
was dried with anhydrous MgSO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure.
The crude product was purified over a silica gel column using ethanol/
ethyl acetate (1/100) to give a white solid (97% yield). 1H NMR (600 MHz,
CD3OD): δ 6.89 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.11 (bs, 1H), 7.33 (d, J = 9.0 Hz,
2H), 7.44 (bs, 1H), 7.97 (bs, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (150 MHz, CD3OD): δ 117.3,
120.3, 124.2, 129.7, 130.7, 137.1, 158.5 ppm. GC-MS (EI, m/z): 160 [M+].
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst (polymer-supported ionic liq.-copper complex)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Concept of Supported Amino Acid Ionic Liquids and Their Application in
Metal Scavenging and Heterogeneous Catalysis
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chen, Wen; Zhang, Yuanyuan; Zhu, Liangbo; Lan, Jingbo; Xie, Rugang; You,
Jingsong
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129(45), 13879-13886

$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 97
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: N-Pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7a General
procedure for the synthesis of carbonylimidazoles The phenylisocyanate
(500 μL, 4.62 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) at rt. The imidazole
(314 mg, 4.62 mmol) dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added to this
solution, which was stirred at rt for 1h. The resulting mixture was
concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by recrystallisation from
hexane to give the N-pheny1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide.
N-(4-Fluorophenyl)-1H-imidazole-1-carboxamide 7e. 7e was obtained from
the corresponding isocyanate in 97% yield (733 mg) following the general
procedure. 1H NMR(300 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 10.34 (br.s, 1H, NH), 8.40 (dd,
1H, J = 1.3, 0.9 Hz), 7.81 (dd, 1H, J = 1.6, 1.3 Hz), 7.50 (dd, 2H, J =
9.2, 5.0 Hz), 7.24 (dd, 2H, J = 9.2, 8.7 Hz), 7.10 (dd, 1H, J = 1.6, 0.9
Hz).

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-p-Chlorobenzoylimidazole: General procedure for the preparation of
acyl-imidazoles and -pyrazoles: In a typical experiment imidazole (20
mmol) was dissolved in distilled CH2Cl2 (20 mL) containing TEA (20 mmol)
and cooled to 0 degC under a steady flow of argon. The requisite acid
chloride (20 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 (distilled) was delivered
dropwise over several minutes to the stirring solution imidazole solution
at 0 degC. The mixture was allowed to warm to 25 degC and stirred at this
temperature for 2 hr to ensure completion. The reaction mixture was then
diluted with 100 mL of diethyl ether, filtered and evaporated under
reduced pressure. Purification through silica gel with hexanes:ethyl
acetate (3:1) furnished 100 % yields. According to the general procedure,
the product was obtained. 4.0 g (97 %); white solid; mp 82-84 degC.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Indium-mediated allylations in aqueous media: an expansion of the scope
and a demonstration of the synthetic utility of the reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bryan, Vernal Jermaine
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM (2000), 62(12), 157 pages

$DATUM 2-[3-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)propyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-3-(2'-methoxycarbonylphenyl)-4-nitro-1-oxo-1,2-dihydroisoquinoline
(18). Iodide 17 (500 mg, 0.9 mmol), potassium carbonate (250 mg, 1.8
mol), and imidazole (615 mg, 9 mmol) were dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (50
mL), and the mixture was heated at reflux for 12 h. The solvent was
removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was redissolved in
chloroform (100 mL). The organic layer was washed water (4 × 100 mL) and
brine (50 mL), dried with sodium sulfate, and evaporated to dryness. The
residue was subjected to flash column chromatography (silica gel),
eluting with 5% methanol in chloroform, to 18. Yellow solid, yield 414
mg, 97% mp 204-206 °C; IR (film) 1724, 1652, 1602, 1515 cm-1; 1H NMR (300
MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.14 (dd, J = .7, 3.4 Hz, 1 H), 7.84 (s, 1 H), 7.64 (dd, J
= .6, 3.4 Hz, 2 H), 7.49-7.28 (m, 2 H), 6.99 (s, 2 H), 6.94 (s, 1 H),
6.68 (s, 1 H), 4.05 (d, J = .0 Hz, 4 H), 4.02-3.86 (m, 9 H), 3.81 (s, 3
H), 3.63- 3.46 (m, 1 H), 2.24-1.77 (m, 3 H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ
165.6, 160.6, 154.5, 150.3, 139.6, 132.7, 131.0, 130.9, 130.6, 129.9,
128.7, 124.2, 118.3, 118.1, 108.0, 102.1, 56.3, 56.3, 44.7, 44.1, 29.4;
positive ESIMS m/z (rel intensity) 493 (MH+, 100); HRMS-ESI m/z MH+,
calcd for C25H24N4O7 493.1723, found 493.1719.
